skills.name: Recognise direct proportion in the form y = kx from a table of numbers
Read values off a real life graph
Work out the equation of a line with a positive gradient from an accurate drawing, supported by a table of values

explanations.A: This is the quantity given by the slope. The dependent variable is the quantity you measure and is usually placed on the ğ‘¦-axis...
explanations.B: The dependent variable is the quantity you measure and is usually placed on the ğ‘¦-axis, in this case it is the distance traveled!
explanations.C: This would be the independent variable... The dependent variable is the quantity you measure and is usually placed on the ğ‘¦-axis
explanations.D: The dependent variable is the quantity you measure and is usually placed on the ğ‘¦-axis...

explanations.A: This would be the dependent variable... The independent variable is the quantity you change and is usually placed on the ğ‘¥-axis.
explanations.B: This is the quantity given by the slope. The independent variable is the quantity you change and is usually placed on the ğ‘¥-axis...
explanations.C: The independent variable is the quantity you change and is usually placed on the ğ‘¥-axis, in this case it is the time!
explanations.D: The independent variable is the quantity you change and is usually placed on the ğ‘¥-axis...

explanations.A: 3 hours would be halfway between the 2 and 4 on the ğ‘¥-axis. Reading up from this point to the graph gives 9 on the ğ‘¦-axis, which represents 9 miles!
explanations.B: You have accidentally given the time taken to travel 3 miles. Read up from 3 hours on the ğ‘¥-axis to the distance traveled on the ğ‘¦-axis!
explanations.C: This would be an estimate for the distance traveled after 3.5 hours. Be really careful when you read up from 3 hours on the ğ‘¥-axis to the graph...
explanations.D: This would be the distance traveled after 2 hours. Find 3 hours on the ğ‘¥-axis and read up to the graph. It doesn't need to be a direct intersection on the graph!

explanations.A: You have correctly worked out that the value you are looking for is 16 squares along the ğ‘¦-axis, but what is the value of this? How much is a square worth?
explanations.B: So close! You have correctly read up from 4 hours on the ğ‘¥-axis to the graph, but each space on the ğ‘¦-axis is not worth $1... How much is it worth?
explanations.C: You have accidentally read off 4 from the ğ‘¦-axis instead of the ğ‘¥-axis. Read up from 4 hours on the ğ‘¥-axis to the amount earned on the ğ‘¦-axis!
explanations.D: Reading up from 4 hours on the ğ‘¥-axis to the graph gives 32 on the ğ‘¦-axis. Each space is worth $2. So for a 4 hour ride, $32 is earned!

explanations.A: I think you have mixed up the dependent and independent variables! We don't do 3 times the miles to get the hours, what do we do?
explanations.B: Looking at the table, we can see you do 3 times the hours to get the miles which we can write as M = 3â„!
explanations.C: I think you have mixed up the dependent and independent variables! We don't do 6 times the miles to get the hours, what do we do?
explanations.D: We don't do 6 times the hours to get the miles, what do we multiply by? How would this change the equation?

explanations.A: We don't do 24 times the hours to get the amount earned, what do we multiply by? How would this change the equation?
explanations.B: Looking at the table, we can see you do 8 times the hours to get the amount earned which we can write as ğ‘ = 8â„!
explanations.C: I think you have mixed up the dependent and independent variables! We don't do 8 times the amount earned to get the hours, what do we do?
explanations.D: We don't do 1/8 times the hours to get the amount earned, what do we multiply by? How would this change the equation?

explanations.A: Not quite! The independent variable is the quantity you change and is usually placed on the ğ‘¥-axis...
explanations.B: This would be the dependent variable... The independent variable is the quantity you change and is usually placed on the ğ‘¥-axis
explanations.C: The independent variable is the quantity you change and is usually placed on the ğ‘¥-axis, in this case it is the distance traveled!
explanations.D: We can't find this from our graph! The independent variable is the quantity you change and is usually placed on the ğ‘¥-axis...

explanations.A: This would be the independent variable... The dependent variable is the quantity you measure and is usually placed on the ğ‘¦-axis
explanations.B: The dependent variable is the quantity you measure and is usually placed on the ğ‘¦-axis, in this case it is the cost of printing!
explanations.C: We can't find this from our graph! The dependent variable is the quantity you measure and is usually placed on the ğ‘¦-axis...
explanations.D: We can't find this from our graph! The dependent variable is the quantity you measure and is usually placed on the ğ‘¦-axis...

explanations.A: The coefficient of ğ‘š is the slope of the graph, so how much is charged per mile, and the constant is the ğ‘¦-intercept...
explanations.B: You have correctly identified the ğ‘¦-intercept, but double-check the slope... For every additional mile traveled, how much is charged?
explanations.C: I think you have mixed up the slope and the ğ‘¦-intercept...
explanations.D: The ğ‘¦-intercept is 1.60 and the slope of the graph is 0.50, so for every additional mile traveled $0.50 is paid. Therefore, the equation to represent this information is: ğ´ = 0.50ğ‘š + 1.60!

explanations.A: The coefficient of â„ is the slope of the graph, so how much is charged per hour, and the constant is the ğ‘¦-intercept...
explanations.B: I think you have mixed up the slope and the ğ‘¦-intercept...
explanations.C: The ğ‘¦-intercept is 5 and the slope of the graph is 6, as for every additional hour $6 is charged. Therefore, the equation to represent this information is: ğ´ = 6â„ + 5!
explanations.D: You have correctly identified the ğ‘¦-intercept, but double-check the slope... For every additional hour, how much is charged?
